These and other findings have led us to explore, in greater detail, the relation between promoter structure and transcriptional activation by the Gal4-VP16 activator (35Chasman D.I. Leatherwood J. Carey M. Ptashne M. Kornberg R.D. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 4746-4749Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar, 36Sadowski I. Ma J. Triezenberg S. Ptashne M. Nature. 1988; 335: 563-564Crossref PubMed Scopus (991) Google Scholar) with chromatin templates assembled with the S-190 extract. First, to investigate whether synergistic interactions among multiple DNA-bound activators are essential for high levels of transcriptional activation in chromatin, we tested the ability of a single Gal4-VP16 protomer (i.e. dimer (37Carey M. Kakidani H. Leatherwood J. Mostashari F. Ptashne M. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 209: 423-432Crossref PubMed Scopus (234) Google Scholar)) to bind to chromatin, to activate transcription, and to induce nucleosome remodeling. Second, to test the relation between nucleosome positioning and transcriptional activation, we systematically varied the spacing between the Gal4 binding sites and the core promoter and analyzed the transcriptional properties of the corresponding chromatin templates. Third, we examined elements of the core promoter and tested the ability of Gal4-VP16 to activate transcription in conjunction with TATA box-driven versus DPE-driven core promoters. The pGIE-n series of plasmids, which contain the adenovirus E4 core promoter with five tandem Gal4 sites (CGGAGGACAGTACTCCG; derived from pG5E4T (38Lin Y.-S. Carey M.F. Ptashne M. Green M.R. Cell. 1988; 54: 659-664Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar)) located at various distances (n + 21 bp) upstream of the TATA box, were constructed by inserting defined fragments (synthesized by polymerase chain reaction) of Drosophila TFIIB genomic DNA (39Lira-DeVito L.M. Burke T.W. Kadonaga J.T. Gene. 1995; 153: 203-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar) between the Gal4 sites and the TATA box. The genomic DNA inserts (of length = n bp) were a nested series of fragments that extended in the 5′ direction relative to the TATA box. For the single binding site plasmids (pG1IE-n series), the five tandem Gal4 sites were excised from the pGIE-n series plasmids and replaced with a single copy of the same Gal4 recognition sequence. The Gal4 site from the Saccharomyces cerevisiae MEL1 gene is as follows: CGGCCATATGTCTTCCG (40Vashee S. Xu H. Johnston S.A. Kodadek T. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24699-24706Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). For comparison of the minimal promoters, five tandem Gal4 sites (also derived from pG5E4T) were placed upstream of the previously described minimal core promoter constructions (41Burke T.W. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 711-724Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 42George C.P. Lira-DeVito L.M. Wampler S.L. Kadonaga J.T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 1049-1059Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) to give the G5min series. The G5min plasmids were the gift of Drs. Catherine George and Thomas Burk (University of California, San Diego), and some of the pGIE-n series plasmids were the gift of Dr. Michael Bulger (University of California, San Diego). All plasmids were purified by alkaline lysis methodology followed by two sequential CsCl gradients. Chromatin was assembled with plasmid DNA, Drosophila core histones, Drosophila histone H1, and S-190 assembly extract derived from Drosophilaembryos, as described previously (20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 25Bulger M. Kadonaga J.T. Methods Mol. Genet. 1994; 5: 241-262Google Scholar, 43Pazin M.J. Kadonaga J.T. Gould H. Chromatin: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, Oxford1998: 173-194Google Scholar). Histone H1 was included, where indicated, at 200 nm concentration in the assembly reactions, which results in approximately 1 molecule of H1 per nucleosome core incorporated into the chromatin (22Kamakaka R.T. Bulger M. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 1779-1795Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). When Gal4-VP16 was added during assembly, the Gal4-VP16 was added to the DNA-core histone-S-190 mix. When Gal4-VP16 was added after assembly, the activator was added 4.5 h after the initiation of the assembly reaction (which was complete within 4 h), and the resulting mixture was incubated for an additional 30 min prior to further analysis. In each experiment, all of the samples were assembled for the same amount of time and analyzed in a parallel fashion. The periodicity of the nucleosome arrays and the efficiency of chromatin assembly were tested by micrococcal nuclease digestion analysis (with the requirement that we observed at least 7, but typically 9 to 12, repeats) and by DNA supercoiling analysis in the presence of 1.6 μm chloroquine, as described previously (20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 25Bulger M. Kadonaga J.T. Methods Mol. Genet. 1994; 5: 241-262Google Scholar, 43Pazin M.J. Kadonaga J.T. Gould H. Chromatin: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, Oxford1998: 173-194Google Scholar). The chromatin assembly process was consistent in the presence or the absence of an activator as well as with different plasmid constructions. The presence of histone H1 increased the repeat length from approximately 170 to approximately 200 bp and caused a slight reduction in the extent of DNA supercoiling, as expected from the increase in the repeat length. Chromatin was transcribed with aDrosophila nuclear extract (SNF), as described previously (20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 43Pazin M.J. Kadonaga J.T. Gould H. Chromatin: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, Oxford1998: 173-194Google Scholar). A mixture of buffer, ribonucleoside triphosphates, and extract was added to duplicate aliquots of assembled chromatin (each containing 75 ng of DNA). The transcripts were detected by primer extension analysis, and the data were quantitated with a Fuji BAS1000 phosphoimager and MacBAS software. The transcription reactions for pGIE-n plasmids were analyzed with the E4 primer (5′-CTTCACAGCGGCAGCCTAACAGTCAGCC), whereas the transcription reactions for the G5min plasmids were analyzed with the M13 reverse sequencing primer (5′-AGCGGATAACAATTTCACACAGGA), except for those carried out with the jockey promoter, with which the Joc primer (5′-CTCGCGACTTCTGTGAACACGTCCACTC) was used. To ensure reproducibility of the data, all experiments were carried out a minimum of two (but typically, several) independent times. The translational positioning of nucleosomes was determined by subjecting chromatin to indirect end-labeling analysis (44Nedospasov S.A. Georgiev G.P. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1980; 92: 532-539Crossref PubMed Scopus (169) Google Scholar, 45Wu C. Nature. 1980; 286: 854-860Crossref PubMed Scopus (753) Google Scholar) in the absence of transcription extract, as described previously (20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 43Pazin M.J. Kadonaga J.T. Gould H. Chromatin: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, Oxford1998: 173-194Google Scholar). Chromatin or naked DNA was digested with micrococcal nuclease, and the DNA (125 ng for each sample) was deproteinized and then digested with BglII andAlwNI. Southern blot analysis of the resulting DNA fragments with probes that hybridize to either end of the region yielded approximately the same locations of the nucleosomes (data not shown). Although the rearrangement of nucleosome positioning was readily detectable by this indirect end-labeling analysis with either one or five Gal4 sites, the disruption of the regularity of the nucleosome array, as revealed by the micrococcal nuclease ladder disruption assay (which reveals changes in nucleosome periodicity within specific regions of chromatin; for example, see Refs. 20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar and 46Tsukiyama T. Becker P.B. Wu C. Nature. 1994; 367: 525-532Crossref PubMed Scopus (563) Google Scholar), was observed with five Gal4 sites but not with one Gal4 site (data not shown). These results suggest that the periodicity of the array is not significantly disrupted by the binding of a single Gal4-VP16 dimer (see also Ref.47Pazin M.J. Bhargava P. Geiduschek E.P. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1997; 276: 809-812Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). The presence of sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins was detected by primer extension footprinting (48Gralla J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 3078-3081Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar) in the absence of transcription extract, as described (20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 43Pazin M.J. Kadonaga J.T. Gould H. Chromatin: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, Oxford1998: 173-194Google Scholar), with the following modifications. Chromatin was digested with DNase I and deproteinized, and the DNA fragments (62 ng) were subjected to a single round of primer extension with Vent (exo–) polymerase (New England Biolabs) and AMP buffer (20 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.9, 40 mm NaCl, 5 mm MgSO4, 0.01% w/v gelatin, 0.1% v/v Triton X-100). Treatment of chromatin with apyrase was carried out as described (20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar). We first examined the extent to which the binding affinity of Gal4-VP16 to chromatin is affected by the packaging of DNA into chromatin that is reconstituted with the S-190 assembly extract. In earlier experiments with either mononucleosome or polynucleosome templates, the packaging of DNA into chromatin has been generally observed to cause a substantial reduction in the affinity of binding of Gal4 derivatives to DNA (reviewed in Refs. 10Kingston R.E. Bunker C.A. Imbalzano A.N. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 905-920Crossref PubMed Scopus (404) Google Scholar, 13Peterson C.L. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1996; 6: 171-175Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar, 18Workman J.L. Kingston R.E. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 545-579Crossref PubMed Scopus (975) Google Scholar, and 49Workman J.L. Buchman A.R. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1993; 18: 90-95Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar). For instance, in the biochemical analysis of chromatin templates that were prepared by the ATP-independent deposition of histones with a heat-treated Xenopus egg extract (containing nucleoplasmin and N1/N2), it was found that the binding of Gal4-AH (which has the same Gal4 DNA binding region as Gal4-VP16) is strongly inhibited by nucleosomes (∼100-fold inhibition with a single Gal4 site and ∼10-fold inhibition with five Gal4 sites (50Taylor I.C.A. Workman J.L. Scheutz T.J. Kingston R.E. Genes Dev. 1991; 5: 1285-1298Crossref PubMed Scopus (204) Google Scholar)). Because we were using nucleosome arrays assembled with ATP-utilizing factors that are likely to be involved in the physiological assembly process (for discussion of ATP-dependent versus ATP-independent histone deposition processes, see Ref. 51Ito T. Tyler J.K. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Cells. 1997; 2: 593-600Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar), we felt that we might potentially observe different properties of Gal4-VP16 binding than those seen previously with either mononucleosomes or with polynucleosomes obtained by the ATP-independent deposition of histones. To this end, we carried out a primer extension DNase I footprinting analysis of preassembled chromatin templates containing a single Gal4 binding site. In these experiments, the promoter constructions were assembled into chromatin by using the S-190 extract in conjunction with purified core histones and histone H1 (22Kamakaka R.T. Bulger M. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 1779-1795Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar, 25Bulger M. Kadonaga J.T. Methods Mol. Genet. 1994; 5: 241-262Google Scholar). (Chromatin assembled with the S-190 extract has been shown to resemble bulk native chromatin by several criteria, which include micrococcal nuclease digestion analysis and electron microscopy (22Kamakaka R.T. Bulger M. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 1779-1795Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar, 25Bulger M. Kadonaga J.T. Methods Mol. Genet. 1994; 5: 241-262Google Scholar).) Then, Gal4-VP16 (at the indicated concentrations) was added to the preassembled chromatin (in the continued presence of the S-190 extract), and the samples were subjected to DNase I footprinting analysis. In parallel, non-chromatin (naked DNA) templates were also tested. As shown in Fig. 1 A, the affinity of Gal4-VP16 to chromatin templates containing a single consensus Gal4 binding site is nearly as high as the affinity of Gal4-VP16 to the corresponding naked DNA templates. These results indicate that the packaging of DNA into nucleosome arrays, under identical conditions that strongly repress (>100-fold) basal transcription (Ref. 20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar; also see later in this work), leads to only a slight (about 2-fold) reduction in the affinity of template binding by Gal4-VP16. To see whether these effects were specific for the synthetic Gal4 site, we additionally tested the binding of Gal4-VP16 to a natural Gal4 site that is located upstream of the S. cerevisiae MEL1 gene (40Vashee S. Xu H. Johnston S.A. Kodadek T. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24699-24706Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In these experiments, we similarly found a slight reduction in the affinity of Gal4-VP16 binding to chromatin relative to naked DNA (Fig. 1 B). These findings suggest that Gal4-VP16 binds with comparable affinity to naked DNA or to chromatin that is assembled with the S-190 extract. It was possible, however, that ATP-dependent nucleosome mobilization factors, which were present in the chromatin assembly extract, might have been able to remodel the chromatin in a manner that facilitates the binding of Gal4-VP16 to the nucleosomal templates. To test this hypothesis, we assembled chromatin with the S-190 extract and then treated the samples with the ATPase, apyrase, prior to the binding of Gal4-VP16 and DNase I footprinting analysis. (In earlier experiments, we had found that Gal4-VP16 at 200 nmconcentration was able to bind to five tandem Gal4 sites in chromatin after apyrase treatment (20Pazin M.J. Kamakaka R.T. Kadonaga J.T. Science. 1994; 266: 2007-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar), but those experiments did not address the effect of ATP depletion upon the binding affinity.) As shown in Fig. 1(right panels), we found that the hydrolysis of ATP by apyrase does not affect the affinity of Gal4-VP16 binding either to a single synthetic Gal4 site or to the natural Gal4 site from theMEL1 gene with chromatin templates. Thus, these experiments indicate that Gal4-VP16 can bind to a single site in chromatin in the absence of ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling activities with an affinity comparable with that for its binding to naked DNA. To test whether the presence of multiple binding sites leads to cooperative binding, we examined the binding of Gal4-VP16 to chromatin with one or five Gal4 sites. Consistent with the single site data (Fig.1), the relative DNA binding affinity of Gal4-VP16 to a single Gal4 site is approximately the same whether the factor is added to naked DNA prior to chromatin assembly, to preassembled chromatin, or to preassembled chromatin that had been treated with apyrase (Fig.2 A). With five tandem Gal4 sites, essentially the same results were seen (Fig. 2 B). (Note that the concentration of Gal4-VP16 that is needed for a complete footprint of the template containing five Gal4 sites ishigher than that required for a comparable footprint of the template containing one Gal4 site. Because the concentration of Gal4 binding sites approaches the Gal4 dissociation constant in these experiments, a greater amount of Gal4-VP16 is needed to occupy five Gal sites per template relative to a single site per template (for example, see Ref. 52Limbird L.E. Cell Surface Receptors: A Short Course on Theory and Methods. Martinus Nijhof Publishing, Boston1986: 73Google Scholar).) Thus, these experiments indicate that the use of five tandem Gal4 sites does not provide any additional advantage, relative to the use of a single Gal4 site, for the binding of Gal4-VP16 to preassembled chromatin in the presence or absence of apyrase. These results thus collectively indicate that Gal4-VP16 can bind readily to transcriptionally repressed chromatin that is reconstituted via an ATP-dependent assembly process, even upon hydrolysis of the ATP by apyrase. Because we observed high affinity binding of Gal4-VP16 to a single Gal4 site in chromatin (Figs.1 and 2), we sought to examine whether a single Gal4-VP16 protomer would be sufficient to achieve transcriptional activation with preassembled chromatin templates. It was possible, for instance, that synergistic interactions between chromatin-bound Gal4-VP16 activation domains are required to achieve strong transcriptional activation.
